sec.title: BACKGROUND:
sec.p: Deletions encompassing a four-gene region on chromosome 15 (BP1-2 at 15q11.2), seen at a population frequency of 1 in 500, are associated with increased risk for schizophrenia, epilepsy, and other common neurodevelopmental disorders. However, little is known in terms of how these common deletions impact cognition.

sec.title: METHODS:
sec.p: Here we used a web-based tool to characterize cognitive function in a novel cohort of adult carriers and their non-carrier family members. Results from 31 carrier and 38 non-carrier parents from 40 families were compared to control data from 6,530 individuals who self-registered on the Lumosity platform and opted in to participate in research. We then examined aspects of sensory and cognitive function in flies harboring a mutation in Cyfip, the homolog of one of the genes within the deletion. For work in fly, ten or more groups of 50 individuals per genotype were included.

sec.title: RESULTS:
sec.p: Our human studies revealed profound deficits in grammatical reasoning, arithmetic reasoning and working memory in BP1-2 deletion carriers. No such deficits were observed in non-carrier spouses. Our fly studies revealed deficits in associative and non-associative learning despite intact sensory perception.

sec.title: CONCLUSION:
sec.p: Our results provide new insights into outcomes associated with BP1-2 deletions and call for a discussion on how to appropriately communicate these findings to “unaffected” carriers. Findings also highlight the utility of an online tool in characterizing cognitive function in a geographically distributed population.
